description.narrative: This project aims to strengthen three programs (TB, HIV, and Malaria) which are integrated into the healthcare system, with a national coordination unit within the National Centre for Endemic Diseases (CNE), with the Global Fund subvention for 2018-2020.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Impact Indicator: -HIV I-9a(M): Percentage of men who have sex with men who are living with HIV. -TB I-3(M): TB mortality rate per 100,000 population. -Malaria I-1(M): Reported malaria cases (presumed and confirmed). Outcome Indicator: -HIV O-1(M): Percentage of adults and children with HIV, known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of antiretroviral therapy. -TB O-4(M): Treatment success rate of RR TB and/or MDR-TB: Percentage of cases with RR and/or MDR-TB successfully treated. -Malaria O-7(M): Percentage of existing ITNs used the previous night. -TB O-5(M): TB treatment coverage: Percentage of new and relapse cases that were notified and treated among the estimated number of incident TB cases in the same year (all form of TB - bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed). Coverage Indicators: -KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services. -TCS-1(M): Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy. -PMTCT-2.1: Percentage of HIV- positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy. -TCP-1(M): Number of notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases. -TCP-2(M): Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases. -TB/HIV-6(M): Percentage of HIV- positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment. -MDR TB-2(M): Number of TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified. -MDR TB-3(M): Number of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment. -CM-1a(M): Proportion of suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities. -CM-2a(M): Proportion of confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antim

comment.narrative: Impact Indicator: -HIV I-9a(M): Percentage of men who have sex with men who are living with HIV: 0- There are no baseline data for this indicator; these baseline data will be provided following the completion of the IBBS study, which will take place in 2018. -TB I-3(M): TB mortality rate per 100,000 population: According to the WHO Report, the mortality rate for TB in STP in 2015 was 3.6 per 100,000 inhabitants. -Malaria I-1(M): Reported malaria cases (presumed and confirmed): 2238 caes. 1- The baseline comes from the 2016 PUDR programmatic data report on malaria. Outcome Indicator: -HIV O-1(M): Percentage of adults and children with HIV, known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of antiretroviral therapy: The result for 2016 is (105/153) = 68.6% Numerator: Number of known and alive patients on ART, 12 months after ART initiation. Denominator: All patients registered and receiving ART during the course of the 12 months preceding the reporting period. This includes patients who have died, stopped treatment or lost to follow-up by month 12. -TB O-4(M): Treatment success rate of RR TB and/or MDR-TB: Percentage of cases with RR and/or MDR-TB successfully treated: 50%. 1- In 2016, 4 cases of MDR-TB were identified in 2014, 2 of which were cured and the other 2 lost to follow-up; -Malaria O-7(M): Percentage of existing ITNs used the previous night: 70%. The source of the baseline is the 2014 MICS Report. At the same time, there are also data regarding the other targets. The MICS is expected to take place in 2019. The target is aligned with the National Strategic Plan; -TB O-5(M): TB treatment coverage: Percentage of new and relapse cases that were notified and treated among the estimated number of incident TB cases in the same year (all form of TB - bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed): The program data indicate a to treatment coverage of 80% (= 148/185) in 2016. Coverage Indicators: -KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV preven

A- Impact/Outcome Indicators -Malaria I-1(M): Reported malaria cases (presumed and confirmed): 1 030,00 -TB I-3(M): TB mortality rate per 100,000 population: 3,00 -HIV I-9a(M): Percentage of men who have sex with men who are living with HIV: No target -HIV O-1(M): Percentage of adults and children with HIV, known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of antiretroviral therapy: 80,00% -TB O-4(M): Treatment success rate of RR TB and/or MDR-TB: Percentage of cases with RR and/or MDR-TB successfully treated: 80,00% -TB O-5(M): TB treatment coverage: Percentage of new and relapse cases that were notified and treated among the estimated number of incident TB cases in the same year (all form of TB - bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed): 95,00% B- Coverage Indicators -KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services: No target -TCS-1(M): Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy: 85,00% -PMTCT-2.1: Percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy: 100,00% -TB/HIV-6(M): Percentage of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment: 100,00% -TCP-1(M): Number of notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases: 200,00 -TCP-2(M): Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases: 85,10% -VC-3(M): Number of long-lasting insecticidal nets distributed to targeted risk groups through continuous distribution: 18 500,00 -VC-5: Proportion of households in targeted areas that received Indoor Residual Spraying during the reporting period: 85,00% -CM-1a(M): Proportion of suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -CM-2a(M): Proportion of confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antimalarial treatment at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -MDR TB-2(M): Number of TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified: 7,00 -MDR TB-3(M): Number of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment: 7,00

bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed): 72,82% B- Coverage Indicators -KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services: 101,1% -TCS-1(M): Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy: 76,60% -PMTCT-2.1: Percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy: 97,10% -TB/HIV-6(M): Percentage of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment: 100,00% -TCP-1(M): Number of notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases: 142,00 -TCP-2(M): Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases: 71,10% -VC-3(M): Number of long-lasting insecticidal nets distributed to targeted risk groups through continuous distribution: 16258,00 -VC-5: Proportion of households in targeted areas that received Indoor Residual Spraying during the reporting period: 69,40% -CM-1a(M): Proportion of suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -CM-2a(M): Proportion of confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antimalarial treatment at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -MDR TB-2(M): Number of TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified: 2,00 -MDR TB-3(M): Number of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment: 2,00

A- Impact/Outcome Indicators -Malaria I-1(M): Reported malaria cases (presumed and confirmed): 420,00 -TB I-3(M): TB mortality rate per 100,000 population: 2,60 -Malaria O-7(M): Percentage of existing ITNs used the previous night: 85,00% -HIV O-1(M): Percentage of adults and children with HIV, known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of antiretroviral therapy: 85,00% -TB O-4(M): Treatment success rate of RR TB and/or MDR-TB: Percentage of cases with RR and/or MDR-TB successfully treated: 85,00% -TB O-5(M): TB treatment coverage: Percentage of new and relapse cases that were notified and treated among the estimated number of incident TB cases in the same year (all form of TB - bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed): 100,00% B- Coverage Indicators -KP-1c(M): Percentage of sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services: No target -TCS-1(M): Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy: 90,68% -PMTCT-2.1: Percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received ART during pregnancy: 100,00% -TB/HIV-6(M): Percentage of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment: 100,00% -TCP-1(M): Number of notified cases of all forms of TB-(i.e. bacteriologically confirmed + clinically diagnosed), includes new and relapse cases: 200,00 -TCP-2(M): Treatment success rate- all forms: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period, new and relapse cases: 90,00% -VC-3(M): Number of long-lasting insecticidal nets distributed to targeted risk groups through continuous distribution: 16 000,00 -VC-5: Proportion of households in targeted areas that received Indoor Residual Spraying during the reporting period: 85,00% -CM-1a(M): Proportion of suspected malaria cases that receive a parasitological test at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -CM-2a(M): Proportion of confirmed malaria cases that received first-line antimalarial treatment at public sector health facilities: 100,00% -MDR TB-2(M): Number of TB cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB notified: 7,00 -MDR TB-3(M): Number of cases with RR-TB and/or MDR-TB that began second-line treatment: 7,00

Waiting for PUDR management letter from GF to validate Impact/Outcome & Coverage indicators. -For malaria the number of cases in 2020 is well above the target (420) but still represents a substantial drop compared to the previous year (2457), translating to an incidence of 925 per 100,000 in 2020, compared to 1,193 per 100,000 in the previous year (population estimates of 210,241 and 205,963 respectively). The target (420) set for year 2020, however is underestimated. The burden of malaria in the country has since changed as reflected by the change of targets in the strategic plan (revised in May 2020 based – projection revised based on actual cases being experienced). The new target was set at 1,716, translating the 1944 cases to 113% instead of 463% (i.e. against the 420 target)). According to a report presented by the malaria program in February 2021 for the year 2020, the country experienced outbreaks in some districts and nationally there was an epidemic situation between week 27 and 51, attributed to effects of the COVID-19 pandemic weakening the activities to fight malaria. Emergency response actions were taken targeting the endemic districts. Active case finding may also have been limited due to the COVID-19. Awareness campaign activities were particularly limited due to the COVID-19 situation. The program plans to undertake several actions including enhancing collaborative efforts by all stakeholders, strengthen the capacity to prepare and respond to malaria epidemics through risk analysis, and boosting awareness raising through mass media (e.g. through radio and telecommunication entities). - For the % of existing ITNs used the previous night, the baseline value of 70% in 2014 was based on the MICS, and another MICS was expected to be conducted in 2019 but was actually conducted 2018. The coverage (74.6%) falls below the target of 85% which was however set for year 2019. According to another household survey on LLIN use conducted by the national malaria program in 2020 (Estudo de avaliacao quantitativa dos mosquiteiros impregnados de longa duracao), major reasons for not having used the net the previous night included not having one (about 20% reported that they didn’t have, mostly due to either never receiving one or it was now too old or damaged), and for those who have it, major reason for not using was that it was too hot. Recommendations from the study was to strengthen awareness campaigns to further improve attitudes towards use of mosquitoes nets. For the current period, the team cited COVID-19 as a challenge in conducting community engagement activities. As a result, they plan to enhance awareness through enhancing use of other communication strategies such as mass media. -For TB mortality rate per 100,000 population (5.7) is about twice the target for the year (2019). The absolute number of deaths was 18 in total for the whole country but with 6 being co-infected, based on the TB program database (HMIS). The WHO Annual TB Report for 2020 did not (does not yet) have the estimates for lower burden countries including Sao Tome and Principe. However, the WHO Annual Report for 2019 (which reports on the 2018 period) estimated it at 21 (8.3–40). -There was no RR or MDR case in 2017 hence no treatment success outcomes for this reporting period. -Regarding the % of adults & children with HIV, known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of ARVs, out of the 125 patients registered in 2019, 107 were under treatment 12 months after starting treatment. Hence this was an improvement compared to 68% for the previous period, and just managing to reach the target (85%). The achievement was attributed to the peer support program in which PLHIV conduct follow-up and provide support to their peers who would be at risk of loss to follow-up (LTFU). The change of treatment regimen to one pill in 2017 was also noted a potential contributing factor. -For DHIS2 for the year 2020 TB and HIV data were entered into the database, except for a few months for some posts. Regarding data entry and handling of the DHIS2 system, the head nurses are interacting well with the DHIS2 system, with only the delay in entering data into the system from the years prior to 2019. However, the major issues are related to the needs of ensuring funds to do the maintenance of the system. 3-To conclude the IBBS study to allow CNE to define the HIV indicator baseline data. IBBS study concluded. The prevention program takes place quarterly according to the National Institute for the promotion of gender. In 2020, 98 different sex workers attended each session, totaling 392 sex workers. The estimated number of sex workers of 425, based on the IBBS, is much higher than the estimate from the previous period (89) reaching 92.2% coverage. Package constitutes counselling for behavior change provided through psychologists, provision of consumables (condoms and lubricants), and voluntary HIV testing. Clients were actively reached at least once, but the client can reach back for further assistance at anytime.
